title: List of number-one Billboard Top Latin Albums of 2006
text:
The <a href="Billboard%20Top%20Latin%20Albums">"Billboard" Top Latin albums chart</a>, published in <a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">"Billboard" magazine</a>, is a <a href="record%20chart">record chart</a> that features Latin music sales information. This data are compiled by <a href="Nielsen%20SoundScan">Nielsen SoundScan</a> from a sample that includes music stores, music departments at electronics and department stores, Internet sales (both physical and digital) and verifiable sales from <a href="Music%20venue">concert venues</a> in the United States.
There were thirteen number-one albums on this chart in 2006. The best-selling Latin album was "<a href="Barrio%20Fino%20en%20Directo">Barrio Fino en Directo</a>" by <a href="Daddy%20Yankee">Daddy Yankee</a>. This album debuted at number 24 in the <a href="Billboard%20200">"Billboard" 200</a> in the last week of 2005; it spent 13 weeks at the top of the chart, more than any other number-one albums in the chart. "<a href="Now%20Esto%20Es%20Musica%21%20Latino">Now Latino</a>" also peaked at number one, spending seven non-consecutive weeks at this position; this compilation album includes music by <a href="Aventura%20%28band%29">Aventura</a>, <a href="Don%20Omar">Don Omar</a>, <a href="Juanes">Juanes</a>, <a href="La%205%C2%AA%20Estaci%C3%B3n">La 5ª Estación</a>, <a href="Kumbia%20Kings">Kumbia Kings</a>, <a href="Chayanne">Chayanne</a>, <a href="Wisin%20%26amp%3B%20Yandel">Wisin & Yandel</a>, <a href="Bebe%20%28entertainer%29">Bebe</a>, <a href="Ricardo%20Arjona">Ricardo Arjona</a>, <a href="Luis%20Fonsi">Luis Fonsi</a>, <a href="Thal%C3%ADa">Thalía</a>, <a href="Alexis%20%26amp%3B%20Fido">Alexis & Fido</a>, <a href="Zion%20%26amp%3B%20Lennox">Zion & Lennox</a>, <a href="Angel%20%26amp%3B%20Khriz">Angel & Khriz</a>, <a href="Cristian%20Castro">Cristian Castro</a>, <a href="Reik">Reik</a>, <a href="Sin%20Bandera">Sin Bandera</a> and <a href="Alejandro%20Fern%C3%A1ndez">Alejandro Fernández</a>.
"<a href="MTV%20Unplugged%20%28Ricky%20Martin%20album%29">MTV Unplugged</a>" by <a href="Ricky%20Martin">Ricky Martin</a> spent one week at the top of the chart on November 22, 2006, and won the <a href="Latin%20Grammy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Pop%20Vocal%20Album%2C%20Male">Latin Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Album</a>; this album was replaced at number one by "<a href="Navidades">Navidades</a>" by <a href="Luis%20Miguel">Luis Miguel</a>, an album that received a <a href="Grammy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Latin%20Pop%20Album">Grammy Award nomination for Best Latin Pop Vocal Album</a>. With the highest charting debut by a <a href="reggaeton">reggaeton</a> artist, <a href="Don%20Omar">Don Omar</a>'s "<a href="King%20of%20Kings">King of Kings</a>" entered at number seven on the "Billboard" 200 with 68,000 units sold. This album also peaked at number one for 11 weeks on this chart.
Mexican rock band <a href="Man%C3%A1">Maná</a>, with his first studio album since 2002, "<a href="Amar%20Es%20Combatir">Amar Es Combatir</a>", entered the "Billboard" 200 at number four, making it the highest-charting debut for a Spanish-language album for a duo or group. With 30,000 units sold in its first week, <a href="Paulina%20Rubio">Paulina Rubio</a> debuted at number 25 in the "Billboard" 200 and achieved her third number-one album on this chart with "<a href="Ananda%20%28album%29">Ananda</a>", after her albums "<a href="Paulina%20%28album%29">Paulina</a>" and "<a href="Pau-Latina">Pau-Latina</a>" accomplished it in 2001 and 2004, respectively. <a href="Luny%20Tunes">Luny Tunes</a> and <a href="Tainy">Tainy</a> with "" and <a href="Hector%20El%20Father">Hector El Father</a> with "<a href="Los%20Rompe%20Discotekas">Los Rompe Discotekas</a>" peaked at number one for the first time in their careers. With "<a href="Trozos%20de%20Mi%20Alma%2C%20Vol.%202">Trozos de Mi Alma, Vol. 2</a>", singer-songwriter <a href="Marco%20Antonio%20Sol%C3%ADs">Marco Antonio Solís</a> peaked at number one for the sixth time in his career.
